answers.text: Chinese government is far too unwieldy to effectively and equitably manage the country's affairs

qas.question: How long has China been with centralized power?

plausible_answers.text: China is the largest unitary state in the world by both population and land area

qas.question: What are Chinese nationalist in favor of?
What are Chinese socialists suspicious of?

plausible_answers.text: Chinese government is far too unwieldy to effectively and equitably manage the country's affairs

qas.question: Why is China's government not similar to unity structure?
How long has China been without centralized power?

context: <a0_0><b4_0>China is the largest unitary state in the world by both population and land area<b4_0/><a0_0/>. Although China has had long periods of central rule for <a3_0><b8_0>centuries<b8_0/><a3_0/>, it is often argued that the unitary structure of the <a2_0><b7_0>Chinese government is far too unwieldy to effectively and equitably manage the country's affairs<b7_0/><a2_0/>. On the other hand, Chinese nationalists are suspicious of <a1_0><b5_0><b6_0>decentralization<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/> as a form of secessionism and a backdoor for national disunity; still others argue that the degree of autonomy given to provincial-level officials in the People's Republic of China amounts to a de facto federalism.
